goals.goal: the student satisfies the basic eligibility requirements for student aid

controls.text: The data action below should only be sent if the global input value for "the existing student's ID" was set
Load existing student details
Hi the existing student's name
There are many grants, scholarships, loans and work-study programs available to help students throughout their university studies.
This interview will help you determine whether any of these resources may be appropriate for you.
The values on this screen will be populated from loaded student details if the custom data action on the previous screen executed

controls.question: Name:
controls.fieldName: the student's name
the student's gender

controls.question: Citizenship/immigration status:
controls.fieldName: the student's citizenship/immigration status

controls.question: Do you have a Social Security Number?
controls.fieldName: the student has a valid Social Security Number

controls.question: Enrollment status:
controls.fieldName: the student's enrollment status

controls.question: Are you from the Republic of the Marshall Islands?
controls.fieldName: the student is from the Republic of the Marshall Islands

controls.question: Are you from the Federated States of Micronesia?
controls.fieldName: the student is from the Federated States of Micronesia

controls.question: Are you from the Republic of Palau?
controls.fieldName: the student is from the Republic of Palau

controls.question: How many people are in your family?
controls.fieldName: the number of people in the student's family

controls.question: What is your annual family income?
controls.fieldName: the student's annual family income

controls.text: You have indicated that you are not a US citizen, US National or US permanent resident, therefore you need to provide further information about your immigration status.

controls.question: Do you have an Arrival-Departure Record (I-94) from US Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS)?
controls.fieldName: the student has an Arrival-Departure Record _I-94_ from US Citizenship and Immigration Services _USCIS_

controls.question: What is the designation on your Arrival-Departure Record (I-94) from US Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS)?
controls.fieldName: the designation on the student's Arrival-Departure Record _I-94_ from US Citizenship and Immigration Services _USCIS_

inlineOptions.text: Victim of human trafficking, T-visa (T-2, T-3, T-4)
inlineOptions.value: Victim of human trafficking, T-visa _T-2, T-3, T-4_

controls.text: SCOTT - The value of the (None of the above) item above still has the (brackets) in it, because that value isn't needed in rules, and I want to ensure brackets are OK in a value when rules aren't depending on it.

controls.question: What is the issue date of your Arrival-Departure Record (I-94) from US Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS)?
controls.fieldName: the issue date of the student's Arrival-Departure Record _I-94_ from US Citizenship and Immigration Services _USCIS_

controls.question: Is the student paroled into the US for at least one year?
controls.fieldName: the student is paroled into the US for at least one year

controls.question: Is the student able to provide evidence from the USCIS that the student is in the US for other than a temporary purpose?
controls.fieldName: the student is able to provide evidence from the USCIS that the student is in the US for other than a temporary purpose

controls.question: Does the student intend to become a US citizen or permanent resident?
controls.fieldName: the student intends to become a US citizen or permanent resident

controls.question: Have you maintained satisfactory academic progress in college or career school?
controls.fieldName: the student has maintained satisfactory academic progress in college or career school

controls.text: Note: Satisfactory academic progress is a school's standards for satisfactory academic progress toward a degree or certificate offered by that institution. Check with your school to find out its standards.

controls.question: Do you have a high school diploma?
controls.fieldName: the student has a high school diploma

controls.question: Do you have a General Educational Development (GED) certificate?
controls.fieldName: the student has a General Educational Development _GED_ certificate

controls.question: Have you completed a high school education in a state-approved home schooling setting?
controls.fieldName: the student has completed a high school education in a state-approved home school setting

controls.text: Great. Just a couple of final checks. Can you confirm:

controls.question: - that you are not in default on a federal student loan?
controls.fieldName: the student has signed a declaration that the student is not in default on a federal student loan

controls.question: - that you will use the federal student aid for educational purposes only?
controls.fieldName: the student has signed a declaration that the student will use the federal student aid for educational purposes only

rows.text: Congratulations you are Eligible for Student Aid

controls.text: Different Types of Student Aid
Grants and Scholarships

Grants and scholarships are financial aid which does not have to be repaid (unless you withdraw from school). Grants are generally needs-based, whereas scholarships are generally merit-based. For more information, visit the <a href="https://studentaid.gov/understand-aid/types/grantshttps://studentaid.gov/understand-aid/types/scholarships" target="_blank">Grants</a> or <a href="https://studentaid.gov/understand-aid/types/scholarships" target="_blank">Scholarships</a> websites.
Loans

Loans are where you borrow money for your education. Loans must be repaid, with interest. For more information, visit the <a href="https://studentaid.gov/understand-aid/types/loans" target="_blank">Loans</a> website.
Work-Study Program
Under the Work-Study Program, you can work part-time to earn money for your education. This program is administered by the schools participating in the program.
Other Financial Assistance for Education
Tax Benefits for Education

Aside from general student aid, there are also various other avenues for financial assistance. For example, there are tax credits, deductions and savings plans which can help taxpayers with expenses associated with higher education. For more information, see the <a href="https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/tax-benefits-for-education-information-center" target="_blank">IRS Tax Benefits for Education Information Center</a>.
Student Aid for Military Families
There are also financial aid programs for individuals serving in the military, as well as their spouses and children.
Clicking Next will submit your benefit request for processing!

rows.visibleCondition: the student satisfies the basic eligibility requirements for student aid

controls.text: Save student benefit request
Saving your benefit request
controls.visibleCondition: The benefit request is being submitted

controls.text: The message above should be visible while the save-student-benefit-request transacton is processed. After that the below controls will become visible if successful, otherwise only the final control will be displayed.
Thanks the student's name
controls.visibleCondition: The benefit request has been successfully submitted

controls.text: Your request's Reference Number is the benefit request's reference number
controls.visibleCondition: the benefit request's reference number<> null

controls.text: Your details have been saved
controls.visibleCondition: The benefit request has been successfully submitted

controls.text: The following messages may be displayed if an error was encountered with the above data action
Unfortunately there was a problem saving your details: the benefit request's failure message
controls.visibleCondition: The benefit request has failed to be submitted

rows.visibleCondition: the student satisfies the basic eligibility requirements for student aid

controls.text: Decision
Sorry the student's name.
You are not eligible for student aid.
Other Financial Assistance for Education
Tax Benefits for Education

Aside from general student aid, there are also various other avenues for financial assistance. For example, there are tax credits, deductions and savings plans which can help taxpayers with expenses associated with higher education. For more information, see the <a href="https://www.irs.gov/newsroom/tax-benefits-for-education-information-center" target="_blank">IRS Tax Benefits for Education Information Center</a>.
Student Aid for Military Families
There are also financial aid programs for individuals serving in the military, as well as their spouses and children.

rows.visibleCondition: the student satisfies the basic eligibility requirements for student aid

lines.text: the student satisfies the basic eligibility requirements for student aid if
the student satisfies the financial need requirement and
the student satisfies the citizenship/immigration status criteria and
the student satisfies the Social Security Number criteria and
the student satisfies the education criteria and
the student has signed the required declarations for student aid
the student satisfies the financial need requirement if
the student's annual family income < the income threshold for the family size

columns.text: the number of people in the student's family
the income threshold for the family size

rows: 77780 + (7920  * (the number of people in the student's family - 8))

lines.text: the student satisfies the education criteria if
any
the student is enrolled as a regular student in an eligible degree or certification program or
the student is accepted for enrollment as a regular student in an eligible degree or certification program
and
the student has maintained satisfactory academic progress in college or career school and
any
the student has a high school diploma or
the student has a General Educational Development _GED_ certificate or
the student has completed a high school education in a state-approved home school setting
the student satisfies the citizenship/immigration status criteria if
the student is a US citizen or
the student is an eligible non-citizen
the student is an eligible non-citizen if
the student is a US National or
the student is a US permanent resident or
all
the student has an Arrival-Departure Record _I-94_ from US Citizenship and Immigration Services _USCIS_ and
any
the designation on the student's Arrival-Departure Record _I-94_ from US Citizenship and Immigration Services _USCIS_ = Refugee or
the designation on the student's Arrival-Departure Record _I-94_ from US Citizenship and Immigration Services _USCIS_ = Asylum Grant or
the designation on the student's Arrival-Departure Record _I-94_ from US Citizenship and Immigration Services _USCIS_ = Cuban-Haitian Entrant _Status Pending_ or
all
the designation on the student's Arrival-Departure Record _I-94_ from US Citizenship and Immigration Services _USCIS_ = Conditional Entrant and
the issue date of the student's Arrival-Departure Record _I-94_ from US Citizenship and Immigration Services _USCIS_ < 1980-04-01
or
the designation on the student's Arrival-Departure Record _I-94_ from US Citizenship and Immigration Services _USCIS_ = Victim of human trafficking, T-visa _T-2, T-3, T-4_ or
all
the designation on the student's Arrival-Departure Record _I-94_ from US Citizenship and Immigration Services _USCIS_ = Parolee and
the student is paroled into the US for at least one year and
the student is able to provide evidence from the USCIS that the student is in the US for other than a temporary purpose and
the student intends to become a US citizen or permanent resident
the student satisfies the Social Security Number criteria if
the student has a valid Social Security Number or
the student satisfies an exception to the Social Security Number criteria
the student satisfies an exception to the Social Security Number criteria if
the student is from the Republic of the Marshall Islands or
the student is from the Federated States of Micronesia or
the student is from the Republic of Palau
the student has signed the required declarations for student aid if
the student has signed a declaration that the student is not in default on a federal student loan and
the student has signed a declaration that the student will use the federal student aid for educational purposes only
the student is a US citizen if
the student's citizenship/immigration status = citizen
the student is a US National if
the student's citizenship/immigration status = national
the student is a US permanent resident if
the student's citizenship/immigration status = permanent resident
the student is enrolled as a regular student in an eligible degree or certification program if
the student's enrollment status = enrolled
the student is accepted for enrollment as a regular student in an eligible degree or certification program if
the student's enrollment status = accepted
The benefit request is being submitted if
the benefit request's reference number = null and
the benefit request's failure message = null
The benefit request has been successfully submitted if
the benefit request's reference number <> null
The benefit request has failed to be submitted if
the benefit request's reference number = null and
the benefit request's failure message <> null
